title: Unusual customer heads to South Australia bottle shop's beer fridge
text:
Staff and patrons at The Queenscliffe Family Hotel on Kangaroo Island, South Australia were treated to a surprise visit by a very unlikely customer this week: a koala.

Footage of him wandering through the venue attracted plenty of attention online, where it's being doing the rounds on social media.﻿

The koala wandered in on Wednesday and spent about 10 minutes roaming the aisles, assistant manager Nicole Arthur told 9news.com.au.

A koala wandered into The Queenscliffe Family Hotel on Kangaroo Island this week. (Facebook/The Queenscliffe Family Hotel)

"It's not unusual to see koalas wandering sort of around the streets in Kingscote," she said.

"He just wandered down the road and then just walked into the front of the bottle shop that's attached to the pub."

The koala appeared to be looking for a cool spot to escape the ﻿sun.

﻿Arthur said the koala wandered into the main area of the bottle shop and parked himself by the fridges for a few minutes.

The koala appeared to be looking for a place to cool down. (Facebook/The Queenscliffe Family Hotel)

The koala didn't appear injured or in distress but staff contacted a local vet and wildlife services just to be sure.

They also provided a bowl of water for the koala to sip on while he was in the store.

﻿"Somebody from the wildlife group came down and had a look at him," Arthur said.

"Made sure he wasn't in distress, made sure he was OK, and they just left him there."

Because it's so common to see koalas in the trees around ﻿Kingscote, where the pub is located, local patrons didn't make much of a fuss about the koala.

Tourists, on the other hand, were delighted at getting to see one of Australia's iconic native animals up close and personal.

"We just monitored him, made sure they weren't harassing him," Arthur said, adding that humans should refrain from touching or interacting with wild koalas.

"And then he wandered back out."

Though it's quite uncommon for koalas to venture into businesses or homes on Kangaroo Island, Arthur said she doubted this will be the last time it happens at ﻿The Queenscliffe Family Hotel.

"It's just one of those things over here," she mused.

"Nothing's ever normal on Kangaroo Island."

title: Record high gold prices could cripple Larna and Julie's business
text:
Exclusive: The price of gold has skyrocketed to record highs and for small jewellery businesses like ﻿Larna Cooper and Julie Modica's, it's making it harder than ever to stay afloat.

In the five years they've been running Juju Gems Jewellery, a boutique store offering hand-crafted and bespoke pieces in Sydney's south, the cost of gold has doubled.

In the past, they tried to absorb those costs but with the price of gold breaking the $US4000 ($6071) barrier ﻿for the first time this week, that's become impossible.

Larna Cooper and Julie Modica, the women behind Juju Gems Jewellery. (Instagram/@jujugems.jewellery)

"Jules and I have been in the industry for such a long time, we've been through global financial crises and all these ups and downs, but this is next level," Cooper told 9news.com.au.

"Every week we're checking and the gold price has jumped, and it's just adding a lot of extra work to us and making it really hard for us."

Gold prices tend to spike in ﻿times of economic turbulence and inflation worries, as it's considered a "safe haven" investment separate from national economies – so it's no wonder that ﻿prices are surging now.

And while the price hikes are tipped to push Australia's gold earnings to $60 billion in the 2025-26 financial year﻿, it could cripple small businesses.

"It's getting harder for little boutiques like us and artists who create handmade pieces here in Australia," Cooper said.

"We don't want to send anything offshore, we don't want to get anything mass made, but with the price of gold, it is getting harder and harder, and I think you will probably see some small guys like us really struggling."

This week she and Modica made the decision to only honour bespoke quotes for a week instead of months, as prices change so quickly.﻿

It's just one of the sacrifices they've had to make to stay profitable.

The duo have also had to cut down on the amount of gold they use in their jewellery, along with raising the prices on ready-to-wear and custom gold pieces, and constantly repricing their stock to align with the ever-increasing cost of gold.

The cost of making gold pieces like this has skyrocketed with gold prices. (Instagram/@jujugems.jewellery)

﻿"At first, we were just absorbing most of the spikes and wouldn't increase our costs," Cooper said, but it was costing the business too much in lost profits.

Now they constantly have to check gold prices and adjust their own.

It's costing them time that could be spent designing and making the jewellery that pays their bills.

"There's so many struggles with small business right now, and this adds to our daily struggle," Cooper said.

"As a small business, we tend to cut costs by paying ourselves very minimum wages and that hurts, especially with the cost of living ... it does feel like a major setback."

﻿The number of customers willing to pay for bespoke jewellery has nearly halved due to financial strain and skyrocketing gold prices.

And it's probably only going to get worse in the months and years to come.

Small businesses like Juju Gems are already struggling with the cost of living - the cost of gold just makes it harder. (Instagram/@jujugems.jewellery)

﻿Cooper and Modica have been in the jewellery industry for about 20 and 40 years respectively and have never seen the price of gold dip by more than a few dollars.

They don't expect that to suddenly change now.﻿

"We're not going to hold out for the price to drop, although it would be amazing, I think it's just a pipe dream," Cooper said.

Giving up on gold to save the business money isn't an option either.

Juju Gems is all about creating high-quality jewellery pieces that can be passed down through generations and that just can't be achieved with cheaper materials.

So ﻿Cooper and Modica will just have to keep coming up with ways to adapt.

One tactic that has been working well for the duo is encouraging customers to trade in their unwanted gold jewellery to lower the cost of creating new gold pieces.﻿

Juju Gems created this custom piece using gold the client had lying around at home. (Instagram/@jujugems.jewellery)

﻿Millions of Australians have gold lying around the house, from family heirlooms to jewellery they just ﻿don't wear anymore.

What they may not know is that it could be worth hundreds or even thousands of dollars – provided it's solid gold, not plated.

﻿"We have women come in who started accumulating jewellery in the '80s and they are sitting on quite a lot of money," Cooper said.

"And what they're getting back in trade-in is significantly more than what they paid for it."

title: 'I burst into tears': The phone call from a friend that stopped me cold
text:
I remember I was in the car, driving to my sister's house. My phone rang, it was one of my girlfriends.

I answered, chirpy and about to gush about how I'd just met my baby nephew for the first time and was on my way for more cuddles - but the tone of her voice stopped me cold.

She asked me to call her back once I'd gotten home, not keen to distract me with some bad news while I was driving.

BCNA's new campaign reinforces the importance of taking a look. At every opportunity. (Supplied)

But I pulled into a service station instead, insisting she tell me then. She broke down as she relayed the news that our beautiful friend Paula, had just been diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer. Time stood still.

I had so many questions but was also completely lost for words. Parked in the middle of a suburban petrol station, I burst into tears, as I tried to digest the devastating news.

Paula had just turned 33, days earlier. She'd just given birth to her first child only months before that. She was healthy, hard-working, the kindest person you'll ever meet. I didn't want to believe it.

She was too young to have breast cancer! She was still breastfeeding her little girl! She was in the prime of her life! And yet she was now in the biggest fight of her life. It just wasn't fair.

I immediately thought back to my chat with Paula just a few days earlier, when she was telling me about nipple rawness that doctors had linked to general breastfeeding sensitivities.

Since 2000, rates among women aged 30-39 have risen "modestly" according to Breast Cancer Network Australia (BCNA), and more "sharply" for women aged 40-49. (Supplied)

She had also, during the last trimester of her pregnancy, felt a lump under her left arm, but doctors thought that it was most likely a blocked milk duct.

Many women will know that lumps and bumps pre and post partum are often attributed to hormonal changes or blocked milk ducts. But this time, Paula had pushed for more tests.

And sure enough, that lump proved to be much more sinister - Paula was diagnosed with stage 2, grade 3, aggressive HER2 positive breast cancer. Her newborn bubble had burst.

She was forced to immediately stop breastfeeding and a whirlwind of further testing began - CT scans, MRIs, surgery to biopsy her lymph nodes and fertility preservation - ahead of a gruelling chemotherapy treatment plan.

She had chemo for six months - the first three months was brutal, Paula says that part of the treatment is known as "the red devil" for its potency.

She also opted to have cold capping during chemo, a painful process but one that saved about 60 per cent of her hair. Then came months of targeted therapy, followed by the most physically altering process - a double mastectomy.

It was a four-to-five-hour surgery that included reconstruction and involved a recovery process which prohibited her from picking up her one-year-old daughter for six weeks. My heart breaks just thinking back on it all.

But thankfully, through resilience, grace, and incredible medical care and guidance, cancer was no match for Paula. After about nine months, and that debilitating treatment process, doctors gave Paula the news we'd all been hoping for - she was clear of cancer.

READ MORE: ﻿ Routine breast cancer test could be used to screen heart disease

But thankfully, through resilience, grace, and incredible medical care and guidance, cancer was no match for Paula. (Supplied)

She still had to complete some treatment, and while any patient with lived experience with cancer will tell you they're never really "free", it was the end to a significant and painful chapter.

Paula of course lives with ongoing check-ups and the scars of her double mastectomy. But now, those scars are more a reminder of what she's overcome.

She's been able to have another child, and restore normality to her life. And now, she's investing her experience into advocacy for future generations of young breast cancer patients. And she's an advocate we desperately need - today, around three Australian women under the age of 40, will be diagnosed with breast cancer.

The same will happen again tomorrow. And again the following day.

Each year, it's on the rise. Since 2000, rates among women aged 30-39 have risen "modestly" according to Breast Cancer Network Australia (BCNA), and more "sharply" for women aged 40-49.

The network says these younger women are more likely to be diagnosed at later stages or with more aggressive disease.

BCNA's new campaign reinforces the importance of taking a look. At every opportunity. (Supplied)

In Australia, the federal BreastScreen program "actively invites" women aged 50-74 to have a free mammogram every two years.

Women aged 40-49 and 75 or over are instead simply "eligible" for a free screening, but need to proactively contact their local service if they wish to book an appointment. In our busy lives, it's not hard to see how something like that might be overlooked.

That's exactly why BCNA's new campaign reinforces the importance of taking a look, at every opportunity.

They're asking women to "Know Yourself. Feel Yourself", and literally feel around for any inconsistencies when it comes to your breast health.

They want women to give their breasts the same daily attention we give our faces in the mirror. Think about that - how many hours do we collectively spend cleansing, moisturising, applying make-up, to our faces, every single day.

Why not spend just a fraction of that time familiarising yourself with your breasts? In the shower, when you're getting dressed, undressed, on the couch watching TV, or while in the kitchen waiting for a meal to cook. Normalise knowing your breasts.

And if something feels off, get it checked out. You might just catch something early. And when it comes to a breast cancer prognosis, the sooner it can be treated, the better an outcome might be - just like it was, for my friend Paula.

title: Laurence won a High Court battle to have the world's longest name
text:
If you want to address Laurence Watkins by his official government name, it might take you about 20 minutes.

That's because the Sydney man, originally from New Zealand , holds a unique world record.

After a lengthy High Court battle decades ago, the 60-year-old has the world's longest personal name.

Laurence Watkins won a High Court battle to have 2253 names. (Supplied)

Watkins' full name is 2253 words long and it was recognised again by the Guinness World Records after a small change to his 1992 title, revising it from the world's longest christian name to world's longest personal name.

"I always wanted to be a little bit famous," he told 9news.com.au .

"I read the 1989 Guinness World Records from cover-to-cover and that was really the only record I could have a chance of beating."

At the time in New Zealand, there was no law stopping Watkins from changing his legal name to something absurd.

Do you have a story? Contact reporter April Glover at april.glover@nine.com.au

Now, official names usually can't be longer than 70 characters and can't resemble or be an official title or rank.

That wasn't the case when Watkins first petitioned to have his name changed.

"I chose Lord, Duke, King and Saint as some of my names, I sort of rubbed it in their faces, and one of the two laws they changed after I won was that you couldn't have a title as your name in New Zealand," Watkins said.

"But my favourite name is AZ2000."

His world record pursuit didn't come without a court date, though.

It was accepted in the district court but when Watkins went to change his driver's license, the clerk didn't believe him.

Watkins' original passport from 1991 had the extra pages attached. (Supplied)

Watkins was challenged by a registrar to take it to the High Court after he didn't accept his lengthy moniker.

"He called me frivolous, and he said the only way I would force him to go ahead and register my name is if I took him to the High Court," Watkins recalled.

He did exactly that and walked away with the world's longest name.

Watkins' old passport in New Zealand had an extra six pages attached to it to accommodate for his 2000+ extra names.

And his revised birth certificate has another six pages added to the back of it too.

Guinness World Records originally awarded him for 2310 names but was later updated this week to 2253 following a change to the record guidelines.

Watkins said he hoped his newly-revised world record will be in the 2026 Guinness World Records. (Supplied)

The original world record awarded to Watkins. (Supplied)

Even Watkins can't remember all the names and it took him hours to count them out.

To give you a taste: it's in alphabetical order and his name starts as Laurence Alon Aloys Aloysius Alphege Alun Alured Alwyn Alysander Ambie Ambrose.

And it goes on.

"I'm hoping it will be in next year's [Guinness] book, unless somebody in the world beats me in the meantime," Watkins said.

"Even if I lose the world record, nobody in New Zealand can beat my record, because of the law change."

title: Ferrari goes electric with new car but promises same driving thrills
text:
Italy: By now, it's common for almost every traditional car brand to have some sort of offering in the electric car market in Australia.

While EVs make up just 10 per cent of all new car sales, and growing slowly, the introduction of an electric model can bring new customers to a brand and create a new experience for existing owners.

However, many people might be shocked to hear that Ferrari is launching their own full electric car next year.

Ferrari's chief product development officer Gianmaria Fulgenzi stressed the importance of the announcement. (Nine)

Far from a traditional new car launch, Ferrari's gathering of the world's media at their factory in Maranello, Italy revealed only the direction the company was taking as well as the raw and bare underpinnings of the future electric car - the chassis.

The first of three steps toward revealing the car itself somewhere mid-way through next year, today's event was about setting a benchmark for what to expect, and also creating some certainty for fans of the brand that this new EV would indeed be every bit as Ferrari.

Speaking exclusively to 9News, Ferrari's chief product development officer Gianmaria Fulgenzi stressed the importance of this announcement, saying "it's a new chapter of our history".

"It's a very important day for us," Fulgenzi said.

"Let me say an historic day, because we wanted to continue our electrification journey starting many years ago."

Ferrari revealed only the direction the company was taking as well as the raw and bare underpinnings of the future electric car. (Ferrari)

That journey, as he outlines, took the company from their electrified Formula One cars, into road cars like the LaFerrari, SF90 and others which feature hybrid electrified powertrains to today.

"We wanted to complete this electrification journey to develop a completely new car," Fulgenzi said.

"Also to enlarge the customer base for our car."

There is no question, though, that petrol-powered internal combustion engines will continue to be part of the Ferrari line-up for a long time to come.

As Fulgenzi put it, Ferraris will be "not all electric, but also electric".

While announcing this Ferrari Elettrica, the company was at pains to point out its deep knowledge of what makes a car feel great to drive - what it is that creates the thrill of driving that Ferraris are known for.

In fact, they know it, and spell it out well: sound, gear change, braking, lateral and longitudinal acceleration.

The car itself will be revealed somewhere mid-way through next year. (Ferrari)

So can an electric car replicate all these sensations?

Fulgenzi says: "It's not only an electric car, it's a Ferrari."

Simple as that.

"First of all. First and foremost, it's a Ferrari.

"What does it mean? What does it mean that the car that has an electric powertrain, but that creates the same emotion of the other Ferrari cars."

There's a real emotive sense to Fulgenzi's passion for this brand and this upcoming car, based around that driving experience.

"Driving thrills are something that starts in the brain, explode in the heart, creating butterflies in the stomach, and create a very big smile in the face when you drive the car and push you and your companion or your family to use the car massively every day, every moment, because using the car, you enjoy yourself."

Like other Ferraris before it, over decades, the all-electric Ferrari will be born in Maranello, Fulgenzi pointing out the significance of this.

The announcement created some certainty for fans of the brand that this new EV would indeed be every bit as Ferrari. (Ferrari)

"We are very proud to say that every core components are thought, developed and produced in-house," he said.

"Because like we have done in the last 78 years for the internal combustion engine that we produce, we think, we develop, we test our internal combustion engine in-house - and also for the electric components.

"For the inverter, for the battery system these components, the key components for the electric cars.

"So we want strongly to develop them in-house and to keep them in-house, to pursue the excellence and also to guarantee the usability for the car also for the future."

I witnessed the very factory floor where the battery is being assembled from raw battery cells, where electric motors are built, paired with gearing and placed into assemblies forged within a few kilometre radius of each other - all by Ferrari.

We won't see this new electric car until half-way through next year, but here's what we can surmise based on what we've heard thus far.

The Ferrari Elettrica will be a new model and carry a new name.

It will also be an SUV body shape, perhaps similar to the Purosangue which is on the roads today.

And it will be fast, very fast.

A top speed of 310km/h, accelerating from zero to 100km/h in just 2.5 seconds.

A 122kWh battery will provide at least 530km of range and four motors will power each of the wheels independently, each of which can also steer with the front wheels able to be disconnected from the drivetrain in search of range on open highway driving.

The specifications look fantastic, and if the company can deliver on the exterior design in the same way they have the underlying technology, then we're in for something very special.

title: Woolworths pushes back on Pauline Hanson's paper bag claims
text:
One Nation Senator Pauline Hanson has called for major supermarkets to bring back plastic bags, despite them being banned across the country.

The Queensland senator posted a video to her social media pages, which showed her holding a broken Woolworths paper bag with some items inside.

In the video, Hanson claimed the bags were of poor quality, and expressed frustration at the 25c it costs to buy them at Woolworths.

In the video, Hanson held a broken paper shopping bag from Woolworths. (Facebook/Pauline Hanson )

"You buy these cheap, rubbish bags that split and break on you all the time," she said.

"I'm over it, I'm so angry about this.

"And 25c a bag!"

She also called for the return of plastic bags to major supermarkets, writing: "Bring back the trusty plastic bags."

Plastic bag ban decisions are made by states and territories instead of the federal government, but every state and territory has now banned lightweight plastic bags.

Coles and Woolworths also voluntarily got rid of plastic bags in 2018, charging a small sum for shoppers to use reusable bags.

However, Hanson claimed such a charge in a cost-of-living crisis was unfair on Australians.

"You charge a fortune for it, cost of living, people can't afford it, and it's ridiculous," she said.

"I'm sure you're making a fortune out of it."

A spokesperson for Woolworths told 9news.com.au a range of bags are available for customers, and disputed Hanson's claims of poor quality.

"﻿Our paper bags have been available for customers since 2020 and while we continue to provide a wide range of shopping bags for our customers, we ultimately want to sell less of them," they said.

"Woolworths paper bags are regularly tested to carry up to 6kg, and are easily recycled at home in kerbside recycling bins."

title: Judge dismisses Drake's lawsuit over Kendrick Lamar diss track
text:
A defamation lawsuit that Drake brought against Universal Music Group (UMG) has been dismissed by a US judge, who says lyrics branding the superstar as a paedophile in Kendrick Lamar's song Not Like Us are opinion.

Judge Jeannette A Vargas rejected the suit, beginning her judgement by citing "the vitriolic war of words" that erupted in spring 2024, and saying the case arose "from perhaps the most infamous rap battle in the genre's history".

The case stemmed from a feud between Drake and Lamar, which began heating up last year and culminated with the release of Lamar's Not Like Us.

The track became one of 2024's biggest songs, which won record of the year and song of the year at the Grammys, got the most Apple Music streams worldwide and helped make this year's Super Bowl half-time show the most-watched ever.

Ms Vargas said a reasonable listener could not have concluded that Not Like Us was conveying objective facts about Drake.

"Although the accusation that the plaintiff is a paedophile is certainly a serious one, the broader context of a heated rap battle, with incendiary language and offensive accusations hurled by both participants, would not incline the reasonable listener to believe that Not Like Us imparts verifiable facts about the plaintiff," she wrote.

The judge noted that Drake and Lamar both have recording contracts with UMG.

A spokesperson for Drake said the rapper planned to appeal the ruling.

"We look forward to the Court of Appeals reviewing it," the spokesperson said.

Lamar has not publicly responded to the ruling via his social media accounts.

Kendrick Lamar performs not Like Us at this year's Super Bowl half-time show. (AP: Matt Slocum)

Who is Not Like Us about?

Kendrick released Not Like Us about Drake amid a flurry of insult songs — better known as a "diss tracks" — between the artists.

What did Kendrick Lamar say about Drake?

Lamar's song called out the Canadian-born Drake by name and disputed his authenticity.

It attacked him as "a coloniser" of rap culture who's "not like us" in Lamar's home turf of Compton, in the US state of California, and, more broadly, West Coast rap.

Not Like Us also makes insinuations about Drake's sex life, including, "I hear you like 'em young" — implications that he rejects.

Here's a snippet of the lyrics:

"Say, Drake, I hear you like 'em young "You better not ever go to cell block one "To any b**** that talk to him and they in love "Just make sure you hide your lil' sister from him "They tell me Chubbs the only one that get your hand-me-downs "And PARTY at the party playin' with his nose now "And Baka got a weird case, why is he around? "Certified Lover Boy? Certified paedophile…"

Why did Drake sue Universal Music?

Filed in January, Drake's lawsuit alleged UMG intentionally published and promoted the track despite knowing it contained false and defamatory allegations against Drake and suggested listeners should resort to vigilante justice.

The lawsuit also alleged that the track tarnished his reputation and decreased the value of his brand.

Lamar was not named in the lawsuit.

Drake claimed the song amounted to "falsely accusing him of being a sex offender, engaging in paedophilic acts" and more.

He also blamed the tune for attempted break-ins and the shooting of a security guard at his Toronto home.

Drake's mansion was depicted in an aerial photo in the song's cover art.

The digital cover art for Not Like Us. (Deezer)

Not Like Us became a 'cultural sensation'

Ms Vargas said in her opinion Thursday that Not Like Us "dealt the metaphorical killing blow" in the feud between the two artists.

"The song contains lyrics explicitly accusing Drake of being a paedophile, set to a catchy beat and propulsive bassline," she said.

"Not Like Us went on to become a cultural sensation, achieving immense commercial success and critical acclaim."

Why Drake and Kendrick Lamar's feud is great for rap Photo shows A fiery graphic reads "VS" with an image of Drake on the left and Kendrick Lamar the right Why are rap's biggest names fighting? And why is that good business for everyone involved? Here's your answers.

Prior to that, the judge noted as she summarised the back-and-forth insults, Drake mocked Lamar's height and shoe size and questioned his success in an April 2024 track called Push Ups, while Lamar insulted Drake's fashion sense that same month in Euphoria.

From there, Ms Vargas wrote, the insults escalated and become "vicious, personal".

Judge says Not Like Us is opinion

The judge said in making her decision, she considered the forum in which the insults occurred and concluded that the average listener was "not under the impression that a diss track is the product of a thoughtful or disinterested investigation, conveying to the public fact-checked verifiable content."

Ms Vargas wrote that Not Like Us was "replete with profanity, trash-talking, threats of violence, and figurative and hyperbolic language, all of which are indicia of opinion."

A reasonable listener, she added, "would conclude that Lamar is rapping hyperbolic vituperations".

"In the context of this rap diss battle, no reasonable person would listen to Not Like Us and assume that Lamar uniquely had access to credible, provable facts that revealed Drake to be a paedophile," she wrote.

The real winners in Drake vs Kendrick Photo shows A composite image of the rappers Kendrick and Drake both rapping into microphones. Kendrick Lamar and Drake's intense feud risks commodifying and objectifying black people, argues hip-hop scholar.

Universal 'pleased' with outcome

UMG, which is the parent record label for both artists, denied the allegations in the lawsuit.

"From the outset, this suit was an affront to all artists and their creative expression and never should have seen the light of day," UMG said in a statement.

"We're pleased with the court's dismissal and look forward to continuing our work successfully promoting Drake's music and investing in his career."

ABC with AP

title: Kerr's return confirmed, Matildas name squad for England and Wales matches
text:
Sam Kerr is back in the Matildas squad for the first time since late 2023, ahead of friendlies against Wales and England.

Cortnee Vine and Katrina Gorry also feature in a 24-player squad announced on Friday.

Kerr last played for Australia in November 2023, then endured a horror rehabilitation from an ACL tear suffered at a Chelsea training camp in January 2024.

The superstar striker returned for the Blues last month, scoring her 100th goal for the club in her first game back.

Sam Kerr back in Champions League Photo shows Sam Kerr heads the ball as a goalkeeper tries to save. Australian striker Sam Kerr makes another appearance for Chelsea off the bench, getting 23 minutes of playing time but unable to break a 1-1 deadlock with their Dutch opponent.

"Having Sam back in the squad is a special moment — not just for the team, but for Australian football," Matildas coach Joe Montemurro said in a statement.

"Her leadership and presence are invaluable as we continue building toward the AFC Women's Asian Cup 2026 and beyond."

Vine, the penalty shootout hero for Australia at the World Cup, is in the national squad for the first time since the Paris Olympics.

A mental health break, injuries and a difficult start to life in the NWSL with North Carolina Courage had kept her out of the Matildas.

Gorry is due to play for the first time under Montemurro, after missing his first window through personal leave.

"The squad showcases the depth we are looking to build, by utilising experienced players who continue to set high standards alongside the next generation of Matildas players," Montemurro said.

"It will be Australia's first time competing against Wales and there is a competitive history with England, so both games will provide different challenges to test the team, our playing style and the way we play together."

Australia will play Wales at Cardiff City Stadium on October 25 (local time) and England at Derby's Pride Park three days later.

Kerr, 32, has been on limited minutes at Chelsea and is likely to be gradually introduced in those games.

She previously joined Matildas camps in a non-playing capacity as part of her rehabilitation.

It is unclear whether Kerr will retain the captaincy, with Steph Catley donning the armband during her absence with aplomb.

Forward Mary Fowler (ACL) and midfielder Tameka Yallop (hamstring) remain unavailable.

title: PM denies going over Chalmers' head to revisit superannuation tax
text:
Anthony Albanese's request for Treasury to examine a controversial proposal to lift taxes on some superannuation balances is "nothing unusual" the prime minister says, rejecting claims he is planning to rewrite it.

The prime minister said a meeting on the tax policy, which was meant to have begun several months ago, was not out of the ordinary.

"No, there are no policy changes, our policy stands. There is nothing unusual," Mr Albanese said.

"We receive briefings on policy all the time, as you expect the prime minister's office to do. There's nothing unusual about that."

Treasury officials admitted yesterday the prime minister's office met with the department to discuss the government's proposal to raise the tax on superannuation earnings — a policy that would normally be the responsibility of Treasurer Jim Chalmers.

Mr Albanese denied he had gone over the treasurer's head.

The department said it was examining options to address concerns around the tax proposal.

Before the federal government announced a backflip on stage three tax cuts last term, the prime minister and treasurer repeatedly said there was "no plan" to amend the tax cuts.

In the weeks before that backflip, it was leaked that Treasury had been asked to model possible changes to those tax cuts.

Tax increase put on ice

The federal government proposed last term to double the tax on superannuation balances above $3 million, lifting the tax rate on earnings from 15 to 30 per cent.

The change was planned to take effect from July 1 this year, and raise about $2 billion a year.

How does Labor's new super tax work and why is it controversial? Photo shows A close-up of Jim Chalmers in front of a black background. The proposal to tax earnings for super balances over $3 million, including on unrealised gains, is the subject of renewed controversy following the federal election.

But it has been met with internal resistance inside Labor, and criticism from party elders including former prime minister Paul Keating, who suggested the average young person today would be hit by the tax increase by the time they retired if it was not changed.

More than two years on, the legislation is yet to be seen.

One of the key criticisms is that because the higher tax rate is not indexed, more people will be captured by it over time due to inflation.

It would also apply to unrealised capital gains, like increases in the value of assets like property, which critics say could expose some savers to a higher tax rate even if they do not technically have access to those earnings.

There is concern the changes could undermine confidence in the superannuation system, if it was perceived that long-term savings plans could be meddled with by future governments.

Treasurer Jim Chalmers argues the change affects only about 80,000 of the wealthiest Australians, and that the threshold could be adjusted in the future to account for bracket creep, as happens with income tax.

title: One of the wettest cities faces water restrictions at wettest time of year
text:
Stricter water restrictions could be on the cards for one of Australia's wettest cities as it heads into its wettest time of the year.

Cairns Regional Council is pleading with residents to reduce water use as it scrambles to fix major infrastructure failures at three local reservoirs.

Two water storage facilities are offline due to structural issues, while the city's largest reservoir is operating at just 60 per cent of its usual capacity after it sprang a leak.

Council CEO Ken Gouldthorp said heavy rainfall typically forced the council to switch off its water treatment plants on certain occasions each summer because of turbidity problems.

"It's important that we really manage demand when that occurs," he said.

"Otherwise, we'll run out of potable water, or we'll reduce our pressure to a point that some people will not have a water supply, and we don't want to get to that stage."

The council wants to bring the city's daily water use down to about 70 megalitres. (ABC News: Conor Byrne)

Cr Gouldthorp said the three damaged water storages were "very large … and their particular location and purpose in the system make them critical".

Water security in balance Photo shows A wide elevated image of a city centre intersection in Cairns Cairns needs tens of millions of dollars to shore up its security of drinking water, but advocates say the city also needs to look at ways to reduce the amount of water being used.

"We are doing our best to bring at least one of those back online by mid-December," he said.

The council first flagged the prospect of having to enforce level-one water restrictions before the end of the year, a fortnight ago.

But citywide water consumption has not reduced since then, with daily use peaking last Friday at 87 megalitres.

Cr Gouldthorp said the goal was for Cairns to limit its water use to about 70ML a day, particularly during wet weather.

A wetter summer ahead

The council's edict to reduce water use comes as the Bureau of Meteorology's latest long-range outlook forecasts a wetter and hotter summer than last year for Far North Queensland.

The signal for above-average rainfall in November has also strengthened.

Permanent water restrictions are in place across Cairns, limiting the use of sprinklers to certain days and times.

"The awareness of those water restrictions, I think, has dropped off, and we need people to know about it and adhere to them," Cr Gouldthorp said.

He said there was a "real and genuine risk" the council would need to introduce tougher restrictions if heavy rain forced it to switch a treatment plant off.

"We don't want to go there — our preference is to gain cooperation from the community," he said.

Ken Gouldthorp is urging residents to curb water use. (ABC News: Christopher Testa)

Maintenance decisions questioned

The council is in the process of building a new water intake and treatment plant to bolster its potable water supply.

It has received $390 million in state and federal funding for the $472 million project, due to be completed next year.

But critics of the council say the current issues are a result of chronic underinvestment in the maintenance of existing infrastructure.

Richie Bates, a former Cairns councillor who chaired a water committee, said there had been past failures to address problems that had been flagged as "high priority".

Cairns state MP Michael Healy said there were "legitimate questions to ask" about infrastructure maintenance.

"That is the sole responsibility of the regional council, and I, like anybody, get a little concerned when our water — treatment plants have to be turned off because of heavy rain," he said.

Cr Gouldthorp said criticism of the council's track record on maintenance was "harsh".

"Council has invested extensively in the water security stage one project, but we've been nursing our system through and maximising its potential use while that is being built," he said.

title: Synergy apologises after overcharging customers $40 million in power bills
text:
More than 170,000 customers have been overcharged a total of $40 million by WA's state-owned energy retailer Synergy since 2009, it has been revealed.

The overpayments range from amounts under a dollar, to thousands of dollars, according to Synergy CEO Kurt Baker, who said most of those affected were residential customers.

"We've accepted payments to approximately 170,000 closed accounts, resulting in overpayments," he told ABC Radio Perth.

"In many cases this has happened because Synergy's allowed customers to continue to pay to their closed account, even in the absence of a bill."

Synergy later clarified that close to 174,000 customers had been affected.

Refunds to take months

Mr Baker said Synergy would contact customers directly to issue refunds, but the process was likely to take several months.

"This isn't good enough, it's not acceptable, we've let our customers down, so I do want to apologise," he said.

Some 170,000 Synergy customers have been overcharged tens of millions of dollars altogether. (ABC News: James Carmody)

"Our systems should have identified or stopped these payments being made."

It comes after a report by the state's economic watchdog in July found Synergy had taken $2.29 million in automatic deductions from Centrelink payments from customers whose Synergy accounts were closed, since 2009.

What is Synergy? Synergy is government-owned and WA’s largest electricity generator and gas retailer. It provides 52 per cent of electricity to households and businesses in the South West Interconnected System. The system covers Perth and extends from Kalbarri in the north, east to Kalgoorlie and south to Albany. Source: Synergy website

Synergy's new figures, which Mr Baker said were uncovered by a "comprehensive review" following July's revelations, vastly eclipse the extent of overcharging previously uncovered.

"The total value across the 170,000 accounts is approximately $40 million," Mr Baker said.

" The average amount is $230. More than half is less than $100. "

Synergy said it had since implemented measures to identify when overpayments were made to closed accounts.

It said it was working with the state government's independent reviewers to identify potential improvements to its system.

Lack of trust

WA's Shadow Energy Minister Steve Thomas said Synergy's overcharging fiascos had eroded public trust in the utility.

Synergy provides 52 per cent of electricity to customers in the South West Interconnected System. (ABC News: Glyn Jones)

"The first question is how on earth does a closed account accept payments? Once you close your account, your account should be closed," he told ABC Radio Perth.

" That should be an absolute red light. "

"How do people trust Synergy to get their bills right?

"Twice now this year, it's been proved that that trust is misplaced."

title: Shortage of smaller homes a challenge for would-be downsizers
text:
Gary, who lives in the affluent Perth suburb of Wembley, summed up the dilemma of many retired would-be downsizers at an ABC Radio Perth live radio forum.

"I live in a five-bedroom house with just my boomerang son, who keeps leaving and coming back," he said.

"I have a hobby that requires a yard.

"I'd be happy with a two-by-one, but there just aren't any where I want to live.

" We don't all want to live in an apartment. I'd like to stay in my area, so I guess I'll just be staying put. "

Loading...

His experience was emblematic of the dilemma many older people face.

They have a large family house, long after the kids have grown up and left home, with more bedrooms than they need but with deep connections in their suburb, and few smaller homes to downsize to.

Many bedrooms, too few houses

A recent report by property data firm Cotality found that 61 per cent of households in Australia contain just one or two people, yet most of the housing is built for larger families.

It found 76 per cent of housing has three or more bedrooms, and just 18 per cent are two-bedroom dwellings.

Property investment advisor Damian Collins told the forum, "we don't have a shortage of bedrooms, we have a shortage of houses".

Most houses built in Perth have at least three bedrooms, as that is more profitable for developers, architect Michelle Blakely says. (ABC News: Gian De Poloni)

In some areas of Perth, people wanting to downsize while staying in the same neighbourhood face almost no options.

"For example, in Lesmurdie [in the Perth foothills] in the last 12 months, there have been 113 house sales, and just one unit sold," Mr Collins said.

"And that's not because there's not demand for it, there's just no stock.

"There are dozens of suburbs across Perth where we just don't have that choice, and 80 per cent of people, when they downsize, they want to stay in their local community.

Mr Collins said while the issue was reflective of Australia's current housing crisis, there had also been long-term resistance from many local communities to building medium-density housing.

"In City Beach, a number of years ago, they were going to bring in duplexes — or maisonettes — on corners, and there was a mini revolution at the community level. They didn't want that," he said.

"I think as a community, if we're going to embrace downsizing and housing diversity, we have to allow that choice of housing in each community."

Townhouses, like these homes built on 80 square metres at Ellenbrook, north of Perth, are a rare sight in Perth's suburbs. (ABC Radio Perth: Emma Wynne)

Building industry preferences

Architect Michelle Blakeley said there was also a lack of support from builders and developers for smaller townhouses and units.

"You go onto the websites of any of the big builders, and you will only find three-bedroom, two-bathroom, games room, computer room houses with a double garage under the main roof," she said.

"We've actually spoken to some of the bigger builders about coming down to a two-bedroom, one bathroom house. They're just not interested.

"And people are reluctant to buy a two-bedroom, one bathroom house, because they've been convinced that it's a better investment to have a three-bedroom."

Asset-rich, cash-poor

For many would-be downsizers, the sale of the family home would involve buying another home and paying stamp duty. Then, any cash leftover from the sale would be considered in the pension assets test, potentially reducing a retiree's payments.

For Don from Maylands, it's an impossible equation.

"We've been looking for a couple of years at the options for downsizing," he told the panel.

"And every single time we come up against a financial barrier that says, no, it's not worth our while to do it.

"That's irrespective of availability, or any of the other constraints that are in there. That financial cost of moving from one place to another is just prohibitive."

The audience listens and asks questions at the ABC Radio Perth Mornings Spotlight forum on downsizing. (ABC News: Emma Wynne)

Mark Kinsella, chief executive of the Council on the Ageing WA, said it was a common story.

"I went and saw a guy the other day. He's living in a $2 million property, beautiful home," Mr Kinsella said.

"It's been his family home for 30 years, but he's on a full pension. He's broke. He has no money, very little superannuation, and he's barely limping by.

"And he said to me: 'If I were to sell this property, I would lose it all. I'd lose all my pension. I'd have to go and find somewhere to live and that would be really hard for me. I would pay stamp duty. I would pay all these costs.'"

Advice to plan early

But Mr Kinsella cautioned against simply deciding that downsizing was too hard, stressing it was better to plan for your needs in old age early, before the situation became a crisis.

"I think it's really important that your home meets your needs as you age," he said.

"Ask yourself, are you in an environment that you're safe in? Is it going to meet your caring needs?

"What breaks my heart is we hear from older people all the time who have stayed in their home, I believe, too long, and then their needs change and they can no longer stay in that home, and the family is then forced to do a fire sale of their property.

" Choose something that's going to work for you now, so you can age in your new home, rather than family making this decision when someone's in a hospital bed and they've got very few options. "

He said deciding while still well gave people time to figure out their options.

"Many older people maybe haven't been in the property market for 30 years," he said.

"Start to get yourself familiar with how the property market works, hearing what agents are good to work with, what developers are good to work with, who you want to trust, and start that conversation."

title: Landowner says PFAS contamination knocked $400,000 off property value
text:
When Christine Stasch purchased her country property in central Queensland, she was lured by its natural beauty and picturesque surroundings for her children and grandchildren to be raised on.

From running livestock to growing fruit and vegetable crops, it has been a peaceful way of life for her family for nearly 20 years.

But Ms Stasch's property is now at the centre of a battle with authorities for compensation after discovering per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances, known as PFAS, in soil and groundwater on her rural paradise.

The property at Pink Lily, a small rural locality on the outskirts of Rockhampton, shares a common boundary with the city's airport, where firefighting foams containing PFAS were used over several decades.

Christine Stasch's Pink Lily property backs onto the Rockhampton Airport. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

A federal parliamentary inquiry is investigating whether urgent remediation is needed.

Ms Stasch said she purchased her irrigated property in 2006 and lived there until 2023.

It is now being rented, although Ms Stasch is hoping to sell.

"I was contacted by Airservices Australia in January 2024, who stated that they suspected that my property had been contaminated with PFAS that had leached from the fire training site," she said.

" They asked if they could run tests on the water and soil at that time, and as I had tenants living on the property, I felt obligated to get the tests done. "

Results from samples collected confirmed PFAS in the groundwater and soil. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

Airservices Australia is a government-owned organisation funded by the aviation industry.

Ms Stasch said multiple tests were completed in March 2024 and confirmed her property and groundwater had varying "unacceptable levels" of PFAS contamination, above the current national guidelines.

Proposed remediation works

Last month, Ms Stasch appeared before a Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for a public hearing in Rockhampton, along with representatives from Airservices Australia, to be heard alongside other submissions, including from federal Member for Capricornia Michelle Landry.

They were told the total estimated cost of the proposed remediation works at the former site — a non-operational area of the airport — was $24.975 million, which included an ongoing monitoring program.

Airservices Australia holds the lease for the site at Rockhampton Airport and is working to develop a remediation plan. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

"Airservices Australia continues to work with Rockhampton Airport and relevant authorities to investigate and appropriately manage legacy PFAS impacts at our leased sites at the airport," an Airservices Australia spokesperson said.

"Should the committee approve the proposal, Airservices will begin remediation works immediately."

No date has been given for when the committee will release the report.

Ms Landry said the residents of Pink Lily were rightly alarmed by the serious and lasting effects of PFAS contamination.

Michelle Landry says families already grappling with the uncertainty of contamination are facing financial and emotional strain. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

"There needs to be some serious thought about compensation [from Airservices Australia] for these people," she said.

"But I also think that we need to be looking further afield of how far this [PFAS contamination] has gone and how much land's been affected by this and also our waterways."

Answering your PFAS questions Photo shows A man in a laboratory wearing a white jacket and safety glasses with a device in his hand As Australians figure out how to live with so-called "forever chemicals", we've asked leading PFAS experts to help us understand the risks.

Ms Stasch said the value of her property had fallen by nearly $400,000 since the discovery of the contamination.

"I got an independent valuer who valued the property, as it is, in current market in August last year and they valued it at $610,000 at that particular time," she said.

"But with the PFAS [testing] report, they felt that it was worth only about $215,000.

" Personally, I may have to abandon my retirement plans. "

The Stasch family had livestock and shared many special memories over the years at their Pink Lily home. (Supplied: Christine Stasch)

Ms Stasch now lives in Mareeba, in far north Queensland, where she plans to retire.

She said aside from the falling value of her property, the stress of having to fight for compensation was taking a toll on her health.

In a statement, Airservices Australia said it would not comment on individual matters, but accepted that people had concerns if they lived near airports where PFAS had been used.

Studies show PFAS does impact human health

While Ms Stasch had a dedicated drinking tap and water tank for her family and now tenants, groundwater was run through the house before she was notified about the possible PFAS contamination.

"Over the years, I have run livestock on the property and irrigated the pastures with the water from the bore," she said.

"It was in the kitchen for washing dishes and cleaning vegetables or whatever needed doing."

New water tanks were installed on Ms Stasch's property after the detection of PFAS. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

Ms Stasch said following the PFAS testing, Airservices Australia offered to provide household water tanks, which it had done.

Shaneel Chandra, a senior lecturer in chemistry at CQUniversity, said PFAS was used in firefighting foam for decades and is also commonly found in household items such as non-stick cookware and cleaning products.

Dr Chandra said the durability of PFAS, commonly referred to as "forever chemicals", meant it could persist in the environment for a long time, including in humans and animals.

Shaneel Chandra says PFAS chemicals are known for their ability to effectively resist heat, stains, grease and water. (Supplied: CQUniversity)

"If PFAS comes in contact with water, that water becomes an agent for the PFAS molecules to spread in other places," he said.

"So, water is really the medium by which PFAS gets transported over wider, bigger areas, like in this case."

Dr Chandra said the potential impacts on human health had been the subject of extensive research over the years.

"These studies show there are definite impacts in humans, including impacts on the immune system, high cholesterol, it impacts the liver, and is also seen as a possible cancer risk," he said.

Landholders like Christine Stasch want urgent government action taken. (ABC Capricornia: Aaron Kelly)

Ms Stasch wishes she had known about the contamination earlier.

"If I had been informed earlier, I'm certain that it would have made a huge difference to how I used the water," she said.

title: Sydney industrial sites ramp-up noise monitoring over humming sound
text:
Two industrial businesses in Sydney's north-west will be required to ramp-up noise monitoring after the NSW environmental watchdog identified them as the potential sources of a disturbing humming sound.

Residents in Ermington and Rydalmere have been kept awake at night by a low humming sound for the last few months.

Building material suppliers Knauf and James Hardie, which both have facilities in Camellia, were identified as being the potential sources of the noise.

Knauf's Camellia plant will be required to do more noise testing for the NSW EPA. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Stephen Beaman from the NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA) told ABC Radio Sydney the companies would be required to engage an independent noise expert to help find the noise and identify solutions.

"Following our investigations [the EPA] issued some legally-binding conditions on two companies out of the Camellia peninsula," Mr Beaman said.

"Those conditions require them to engage an independent noise expert to thoroughly go through each facility and look for potential sources of noises and come up with remedial strategies to address it."

A James Hardie premises is one of two businesses identified as the potential source of the disturbing noise. (ABC Radio Sydney: Declan Bowring)

Mr Beaman said the EPA matched the pitch and loudness of the Rydalmere noise to that coming from the Camellia premises.

He says both businesses have accepted the noise assessment requirement.

"So far the businesses have been cooperating," Mr Beaman said.

The businesses will have to report to the EPA by November 26.

Meanwhile, a 24-hour noise monitoring device in Rydalmere has been set up by the EPA and will be reviewed weekly for a month.

Industrial businesses cooperating

A spokesperson for Knauf said it would work closely with the EPA.

"We have operated at this site for more than 50 years, with no significant changes to our operations in recent years," the spokesperson said.

" We value being a good neighbour and will continue cooperating with the EPA. "

Previously, Knauf said it did not believe it was responsible for the noise.

The humming noise was identified as coming from the Camellia industrial area. (ABC)

James Hardie has been contacted for comment.

A spokesperson previously told ABC Radio Sydney James Hardie was also cooperating with the EPA's investigations.

"While we're not aware of any changes to our manufacturing operations in recent weeks or months that would suggest that our operation is the source of concern, we are assisting the EPA with their investigations," they said at the time.

Relief for residents

Rydalmere resident Maddi Pettit told ABC Radio Sydney the noise had been reduced but was still audible in her neighbourhood.

Loading...

"It has gotten better but it hasn't completely gone away," Ms Pettit said.

" A lot of people are still being kept awake. It's quite exhausting and it's not sustainable for the community. "

Ermington resident Brenton Potter was inspired to drive around at night to find the source of the noise in September.

He said he had not noticed the noise at his home since the end of that month.

Mr Beaman said concrete-batching plant Hymix was also investigated but it did not have the same noise signature that was picked up in Rydalmere.

He said the facility was excessively noisy and the EPA would keep working with the company to mitigate noise.

title: Meet Hayden Eastbury, the 17-year-old visiting every ABC bureau in Australia
text:
Hayden Eastbury has two great passions in life — garbage trucks and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

It was the 17-year-old's love for the ABC that inspired his epic journey across the country with his family.

Loading...

"I've been travelling around Australia with my family, and have been meeting ABC news presenters," Hayden said.

Hayden, his brother, Jake, and their parents set off from Newcastle in mid-2024 with plans to visit all 68 ABC offices in Australia, fuelling Hayden's dream of one day working for the corporation.

"We've been to Queensland, Northern Territory, down the coast, Western Australia; I've met lots of people and been given lots of ABC stickers," Hayden said.

Hayden Eastbury got a taste behind the news desk at the ABC studios in East Perth. (ABC News: Kenith Png)

Teaching through learning

Hayden and his brother both live with fragile X syndrome, a mutation of the X chromosome.

The genetic condition can include a wide range of physical, intellectual and behavioural symptoms.

According to the Fragile X Association of Australia, it is the leading cause of inherited intellectual disability, affecting about 1 in 4,000 males and around 1 in 6,000 females.

The family is hoping to spread awareness for fragile X syndrome. (ABC Great Southern: Kate Forrester)

Hayden's father, Phil, hopes the journey will inspire greater awareness and understanding of the syndrome nationwide.

"Both Hayden and his brother, Jake, live with a lot of challenges but as we've explored this great country, we've encountered so many people who have been so supporting of us, like the ABC," Phil said.

Phil noted that while awareness of the syndrome was growing, a significant number of people remained unaware they could be carriers.

Phil and Hayden Eastbury met WA presenter Pamela Medlen in the Perth studios. (ABC News: Kenith Png)

"Fragile X is inherited through the X chromosome, so my boys inherited it from my wife's side," Phil said.

"Symptoms can be put down to things like Dyslexia, men can have tremors that look like Parkinson's, for women, they can be put down to early onset menopause.

"It's only when it mutates to the full fragile X do alarm bells ring — that's generally through early childhood when milestones aren't met."

" The boys will need supporting for the rest of their lives but we love parenting them, it's an absolute pleasure to have them in our lives. "

Hayden Eastbury hopes one day to work at the ABC. (Supplied: Phil Eastbury)

Life-long dream

Hayden's passion for news and current affairs started with his favourite presenter.

"Hayden loves to listen to the banter," Phil said.

"Lisa Millar is his favourite presenter on ABC, we're hoping to one day catch up with her."

"I love Backroads at 8pm on the ABC," Hayden added.

Hayden Eastbury got the chance to try his hand at radio presenting at the ABC Darwin studios. (Supplied: Phil Eastbury)

The road trip will be put on hold when Hayden returns to Newcastle next year to finish year 12, but Phil says it will resume once Hayden completes his secondary studies.

"If he could one day score a job with the national broadcaster, that would be brilliant," Phil said.

If that does not work out, Hayden is equally fascinated by his other passion.

"I think one day if he could get a job with something garbage-related, that would suit Hayden," Phil added.

"I don't think he will be able to get a drivers' licence, which is a big part of driving a [garbage truck], but if he could get something related, that would be great."

Hayden Eastbury and his family have been travelling through Western Australia, visiting offices in the northern region. (Supplied: Phil Eastbury)

A “shattered” Aleer woke up in Barcelona to the life-changing news after previously requesting a trade to the Saints to accept a four-year deal worth north of $700,000 annually.

Conor Stone chases the footy in 2024. Credit: Getty Images

The Giants are happy to bring the 24-year-old defender back to the club, but they will need to do some re-jigging to fit him in, given the league’s list rules. There is also a chance another team emerges as an Aleer suitor.

AFL clubs can have between 36 and 38 players on their primary list, and GWS are already at 35 before trading for Melbourne midfielder Clayton Oliver or potentially re-signing Aleer.

The challenge for the Giants is they must make at least three national draft selections, so Oliver’s arrival - at minimum - would mean something has to give.

Stone, 23, re-signed for two seasons in October last year after Essendon expressed interest in him.

One of those sources said the 20-gamer would be at the Giants next season.

GWS may need to delist Stone and a second player if Aleer re-signs, unless they traded a player or two out, potentially in the Oliver deal.

text:
The clubs have held a meeting with the NRL over the threat of Rugby 360 and backed the governing body as it explores legal options regarding protective measures and sanctions for defecting players and agents.

NRL chief executive Andrew Abdo spoke to club CEOs in a phone hook-up on Friday morning and allayed the fears of team bosses.

Australian Rugby League Commission boss Peter V’landys also spoke with several club chairmen this week. He will take the views of the clubs to the commission to discuss options available to the NRL.

It is unclear whether the NRL has the legal right to ban defecting players from returning, but the code is keen to explore potential measures to protect the sport from a raid on its talent.

title: The top six: Why these young batters are the next big things for Australia
text:
Connolly is one of few Australians to score a half-century as a 16-year-old in an under-19 world cup. He has also captained the under-19 side. Had a key role at No.5 on the recent Australia A tour of India. Fergus O’Neill congratulates Ollie Peake on his match-winning Sheffield Shield knock on Tuesday. Credit: Getty Images Ollie Peake (Victoria) Age: 19

Tests: 0

It’s been a stunning 18-month rise for the son of former Victorian batter Clinton Peake. In this time, Peake played in Australia’s under-19 World Cup win, made his debut for the Melbourne Renegades in the Big Bash League, and posted a half-century on debut in the Sheffield Shield. Then came the invite to be a development player and travel with Australia on their Test tour of Sri Lanka last February.

Loading This week, the slick left-handed batter from Geelong, who describes himself as a “little scrapper”, was the match-winner for Victoria in their Shield clash against reigning champions South Australia. In just his second Shield match, and fifth first-class match, Peake finished unbeaten on 70 from 147 deliveries to guide the Vics home in a testing chase of 231 at Adelaide Oval. Close Shield observers say Peake already has the game to play Test cricket, but here’s a scary thought – he is still young enough to qualify for next year’s Under-19 World Cup. Sam Konstas (NSW) Age: 20

Tests: 5

The sometimes brutal nature of sport has hit Konstas, who enthralled the cricketing world with his audacious ramp shots on debut against Jasprit Bumrah at the MCG last summer, but has since struggled to find the middle ground needed to prosper at the top level.

Sam Konstas, Harry Dixon and Ollie Peake after Australia claimed the ICC under-19 World Cup in South Africa last year. Credit: ICC via Getty Images Konstas has every shot in the technical – and not so technical – handbook, but when to play these strokes remains a battle. “He’s got all the tools, and I think he has the ability when he wants to, to absorb pressure. And he’s got the ability to put a lot of pressure back on the bowlers. He’s going to have plenty of experiences, and he’s going to learn from them along the way,” Australian batting great Steve Smith said. A century for Australia A in India last month settled the nerves, but a double failure for NSW in the opening round of the Sheffield Shield last weekend in Perth means he is line-ball to hold his place in the team for the Ashes. Heavy hitter: Harry Dixon has based his powerful game on his idol, Australian great David Warner. Credit: Justin McManus

Harry Dixon (Victoria) Age: 20

Tests: 0

It would be unfair to say Dixon is a bull at a gate. But he has modelled his aggressive intent on idol David Warner. Dixon has long been on the national selectors’ radar. His century inside a session against England in Worcester during the Australia under-19 Ashes tour of 2023 remains a talking point in cricketing circles. While he has batted in the middle order for Victoria, coach – and former Australian opener Chris Rogers – told the Cricket Australia website he is considering shifting Dixon to an opening role. “If there’s one player that Harry reminds me of, it’s David Warner. He can play shots that Warner – and potentially [Travis] Head – can play,” Rogers said.

Loading Rogers says the similarities include Dixon’s ability to hit good balls just outside off stump conventionally through cover point or more unconventionally through the leg side. Dixon missed Victoria’s Shield opener against the Redbacks after being selected for the overlapping Australia A one-day series against India A, but fans should brace themselves for the hard hitting to come when he returns to local shores over the next month. Will Salzmann (NSW) Age: 21

Tests: 0

“He definitely knows how to hit the ball,” was one comment from a state talent manager, who wished to remain anonymous, to speak freely. That, clearly, was the case in Perth last weekend when, on his first class debut, the fast-bowling all-rounder cracked 43 (seven boundaries) and 72 (10 boundaries and a six) at No.7 and was named man of the match in the Blues’ 74-run win over WA. “There was something lurking within, and he found it in his first game; two fantastic innings,” NSW coach Greg Shipperd said. On the rise: Will Salzmann began his Sheffield Shield career last weekend with man-of-the-match honours. Credit: Getty Images This continued Salzmann’s strong pre-season form, including a century against Victoria in a scratch match in Sydney. While he was given just the one over with the ball in Perth, he will have plenty of opportunity to shine this summer. Hailing from the Campbelltown Camden District Cricket Association, and representing Sydney University in Premier cricket, Salzmann was part of the Australian side that finished third at the 2022 under-19 World Cup, taking 12 wickets in six games, the most of any Australian.

Injury impacted his 2024-25 season, but he has enjoyed a taste of state white-ball cricket in recent seasons, with the Blues now looking to him to be a consistent threat in all formats. “I am really proud of how I have responded physically and the big off-season I have had, but also mentally, tapping into the people in my corner and learning to mature on and off the field. I have high red-ball desires,” Salzmann said. Hugh Weibgen (Queensland) Age: 20

Tests: 0

Usman Khawaja, a teammate of Weibgen’s at the Valley District Cricket Club, has said he expects “big things” from the dashing right-hander, and that’s starting to show.

While he was captain of Australia’s victorious under-19 side at last year’s World Cup in South Africa, and was named captain and No.3 in the team of the tournament with an average of 50.66, Weibgen was made to wait by the Bulls’ selectors. Hugh Weibgen celebrates taking a catch for the Sydney Thunder last summer. Credit: Getty Images But no more. For those who witnessed his maiden unbeaten century (115 not out from 94 deliveries) to lift the Bulls to a two-wicket win over WA in their one-day match at Allan Border Field last month, there was a feeling he is destined for higher honours – and soon. “He’s, obviously, a very good young leader, and that’s something that’s going to come into it at some stage. I would love him to be captain in two or three years’ time for Queensland,” Bulls coach Johan Botha said. Having spent the northern summer playing in the Surrey Premier League, Weibgen was handed his first-class debut last weekend, lashing 39 off 41 balls as the Bulls crushed Tasmania.

title: ‘He just fell’: How Arjun’s last race proved one too many for Bima’s boy star
text:
Save Log in , register or subscribe to save articles for later. Save articles for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them any time. Got it Normal text size Larger text size Very large text size Bima, Indonesia: When he died in a fall at the age of 12, Arjun Bimantara was already a racing veteran. His father had been a jockey. So had his uncles and grandfather. At the age of five or six, it seemed right to the boy and his family that he would start as a jockey too. A natural rider, owners threw contracts at him so big that he bought his own horse for $1000, more than many adults in the Indonesian city of Bima – on the sparse island of Sumbawa – could hope to save in their lives. His nest-egg paid for his mother to go through university. Child jockey Arjun Bimantara was aged 12 died when he died after a fall in 2023. Credit: Amilia Rosa In half a lifetime spent rounding the crude, dirt tracks of West Nusa Tenggara province, Arjun had come off his horses “many times”, his grandfather and mentor, Abdul Malik, says. At full gallop and without a saddle, bodies can slide off. In the suffocating tropical heat, small hands clenching manes and reins can lose their grip. “He just fell,” Malik says. “There was no other horse or person to blame.” Usually, Arjun bounded up and got back on his horse. This time he could not move. Malik ran onto the Bima track, cradling his grandson and urging him to speak. Arjun was slipping in and out of consciousness by the time they reached hospital. Rousing himself, he told everyone he felt no pain and wanted to go home. Ten minutes later, he was dead.

Advertisement

It was August 13, 2023, when Arjun became the third boy jockey in four years to die in a fall on Sumbawa island. The total is now five, after the deaths of eight-year-old Febiansyah Putra in May 2024 and seven-year-old Muhamad Iswan in March. “So much as looking at this beautiful photo makes me cry,” Malik says, clutching his best portrait of Arjun staring confidently into the camera. “No matter what, no other grandchild [of mine] will be a jockey. I lost Arjun on a racehorse, and Arjun will be the last.” Abdul Malik with a photo of his late grandson, Arjun. Credit: Amilia Rosa In the pockets of Indonesia where horseracing remains wildly popular, some jockeys start riding even younger than Arjun. Once, Malik says, he saw a little boy climb off a racehorse to feed on his mother’s breast. There are no weight handicaps or restrictions. The lighter the jockey, the better the horse’s advantage. The children wear helmets, vests and kneepads. Forget about saddles. Kilograms equal centimetres. The money is big, and so is the workload. At a multiday carnival, the pool of boys might be a couple of dozen for 700 or more horses. They are often the breadwinners for their families, catapulting their parents and siblings from poverty to wealth.

Advertisement

According to the Stop Child Jockeys Coalition, a collection of more than 10 civil society organisations, the horse owners are “mostly government officials, police and military personnel, businesspeople, council members, and bank employees”. It is barbarous, exploitation and illegal, says the coalition. The racing crowd on Sumbawa calls it tradition. The barrier gates fly open for the first of the grand finals at the Bima Mayor’s Cup. Credit: Amilia Rosa A lucrative game One of the premier events on the racing calendar in West Nusa Tenggara is the Bima Mayor’s Cup, a 10-day knockout-style carnival put on by the city government with prizes of cows, motorbikes and a total pot of about $50,000. This masthead is trackside for the final two days, mingling with the punters crammed into bamboo grandstands and pressing against crumbling fences. At the barrier gates, army men whip the shins of youngsters crowding too close. The kids flee in excited yips of pain, then creep back like a returning tide.

Advertisement

Drugs for the horses are on open display. Haris, a pharmacist, will make about $3000 at the carnival. “Every single horse is medicated,” he says. “It makes them more energetic.” A collection of drugs available for horses before they race. The injections make them more “energetic”. Credit: Amilia Rosa Never mind that gambling is illegal in Indonesia. Men and boys wave notes of rupiah, looking for takers on their bets. One teenager with a mischievous smile confides that he gets his money from his mum for snacks. “She doesn’t know that I gamble.” The betting and absence of any meaningful oversight to ensure integrity leads to race-fixing and “sabotage”. Between races, a fight almost breaks out among a crowd of men because of such an accusation. Military members and government officials see everything, and do nothing. With no weight handicaps or restrictions, the lighter the jockey, the bigger the advantage. Credit: Amilia Rosa The proud family of Sandi, a winning jockey in one of the penultimate day’s heats atop Queen Sahara, presents him as nine years old. It is not convincing. Minutes after flying around the track to glory on a powerful racehorse, Sandi is so shy at the attention he buries his frightened face into his mother’s waist and refuses to let go of her shirt.

Advertisement

Does she get worried about her son? No. “His father was a jockey, and he is fine. His brother was also a jockey, and he is fine,” she says. “Sandi has been doing this for two years without any problems.” Sandi soon after riding Queen Sahara to victory. Credit: Amilia Rosa A child comes off his horse in a cloud of dust. Dozens of people rush to his aid. The excitable race caller warns against taking photos and videos. The boy walks away, shaken and bruised, perhaps, but otherwise unharmed. “I’m aware of the five deaths, and I’m very concerned,” Saiful, the father of a 10-year-old jockey named Sahban, says. “I would rather that he didn’t ride. I believe I can sufficiently provide for the family without Sahban, but he is very insistent. He is proud and he is good. He is proud of the financial gain for our family.” Child jockey Sahban, 10, insists on riding, his father says. Credit: Amilia Rosa Some jockeys are paid per ride, starting from about $10. Others are booked on contracts worth $600, plus bonuses for the duration of a carnival. Jockeys could have multiple contracts per carnival.

title: Parliamentary sports club drops senator over 'cheap shot' gambling lobby complaints
text:
Former Wallabies captain turned senator David Pocock had been kicked out of the parliamentary sports club for raising concerns about the gambling lobby.





The independent senator has been critical of the Australian Parliament Sports Club for registering as a lobby group, with many MPs who play unaware of its status.





The club hosts friendly games between MPs, their staff, public servants and journalists during parliament sitting weeks and organises pollies versus press games across multiple sports.





Senator Pocock said he raised concerns with the club's CEO Andy Turnbull before going public, including over the gambling lobby's sponsorship.





Turnbull has denied lobbying takes place on the field and says the club was registered as a precaution to be on the safe side, given it brings together MPs and corporate sponsors.



Turnbull said he would deregister the club following written confirmation from the department it did not need to be registered.





But Senator Pocock raised concerns that it should be registered "if there are paying corporate members who interact with parliamentarians".



'You left me with no choice'

Turnbull messaged Senator Pocock on Thursday evening to say "clearly based on your actions this week you have chosen to ignore my comments above".





"You have chosen not to do that and in doing so have become the first person ever to politicise the most apolitical operation in the parliament," he said in the message.





"I have for the last 24 hours just scratched my head in disbelief. It is inappropriate for you to remain a member of the club in these circumstances.





"You chose a cheap shot that will have no effect on the outcome of your anti-gambling campaign. I am sorry it has reached this point but you left me with no choice."

Senator Pocock is among the most vocal critics of the federal government failing to respond to a landmark gambling harm inquiry that recommended phasing out online betting, an advertising ban and stopping gambling inducements.





The government is yet to respond to the review's recommendations more than two years later.
